feed.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System

entry.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: In a recent discussion, the topic of front-running resistance in a peer-to-peer marketplace was brought up. Front-running refers to entering into a trade with advance knowledge of a block transaction that will influence the price, allowing participants to capitalize on the trade. In the context of Bitcoin/CivKit, front-running could occur when a bulletin board operator discovers a batch of market offers and takes advantage of the opportunity before publishing the offer on its board.The discussion highlighted various perspectives on this issue. One viewpoint suggested that if a bulletin board operator can collect outsized profits from their trusted position, other market participants may eventually move to other markets where they can provide better prices. From the perspective of a maker like Mary, she is happy as her order gets executed at the desired price, but it is Terry the Taker who loses out in this model. This dynamic makes the market structure resemble more of a brokerage rather than an exchange.To address front-running concerns, different security paradigms were proposed. One approach involves duplicating the announcement of offers to multiple independent bulletin boards and monitoring latency anomalies. If repeated anomalies are detected, makers can disqualify the misbehaving board from future announcements. Another approach suggests running the bulletin boards as a federation, where incoming offers become consensus items and must be announced to all federation members before being published. This approach ensures that consensus rules are followed and income is earned as a group.The discussion also emphasized the importance of user experience and finding what products people are interested in trading. It was suggested that offering a good user experience and providing better prices are key factors in drawing more market activity. The goal is to have active participants and liquidity in the market, even if it means dealing with some front-running risks.Overall, the CivKit framework proposes a flexible system for peer-to-peer marketplaces, allowing for the adaptation of front-running resistance parameters based on the types of trades and market participants involved. The configuration of these parameters will depend on real-world deployments and the specific needs of the market. While front-running can be seen as a concern, it is also viewed as a sign of active participation and liquidity in the market.In a recent post on the Lightning Dev mailing list, Nick, Ray, and Antoine announced their paper that delves into the architecture of their system [3]. The authors express gratitude to the peer reviewers for their input. They also mention their plans to gradually release code and modules, leveraging the Lightning Dev Kit [4] and Nostr libraries.The team emphasizes their commitment to adhering to the Bitcoin open-source and decentralized standards established by Bitcoin Core. They express eagerness to collaborate with the community in order to standardize libraries and ensure interoperability between clients, all while maintaining a long-term perspective.Feedback from the community is highly encouraged and welcomed by the authors. The post concludes with a friendly sign-off from Nick, Ray, and Antoine.The post includes several links for further reference. These include the paper itself [3], the Lightning Dev Kit website [4], and two external resources - the W3C's DID (Decentralized Identifier) Core specification [1] and the Privacypass project [2].Overall, the post highlights the authors' efforts to contribute to the Bitcoin ecosystem through their research and development work, and their desire to engage with the wider community for feedback and collaboration.
